title: Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training for Family Caregivers
description_brief: Our study is designed to help caregivers of someone with Alzheimer's Disease and related dementia to understand and deal with the difficult behaviors of a person with dementia.
description_detailed: The goal of this study is to develop and evaluate the Caring Response mobile app, containing a training that builds skills and stimulates practice. The investigators are evaluating different materials, which may encourage caregiver participation, enable user interaction, and promote better assimilation of concepts. The research team is designing the program to help to enhance caregivers' skills to deal with difficult behaviors, reduce distress, and improve quality of life.

outcomeMeasures.title: Revised Memory and Behavior Problems Checklist
outcomeMeasures.description: This scale measures the type/number of dementia patients disturbing behaviors, and how much they bother caregivers with 24 items describing possible troublesome behaviors that the patient might evidence in the past month. Caregivers are first asked whether the dementia patient had displayed any of these in the time period, and secondly to rate on a 5-point scale (0=not at all; 4= extremely) how much this "bothered or upset" them. A "conditional bother" score is calculated which is the "upset" or "bother" ratings for only the problematic behavior that occurred. The scale refers to the caregiver. Minimum score (best value)=0. Maximum score (worst value)=4. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: The Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression scale (CES-D) is a 20-item measure that asks about the frequency of depressive symptoms (affective, psychological, and somatic) within the past week.The scale refers to the caregiver. Minimum score (best value)=0. Maximum score (worst value)=60. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Perceived Stress Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: The "Perceived Stress Scale" measures the overall level of stress. This instrument contains 10 items accessing overall appraisals of stress in the past month. The scale refers to the caregiver. Minimum score (best value)=0. Maximum score (worst value)=40. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

explanation_target: Reason: The study ("Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training for Family Caregivers") develops and evaluates the "Caring Response" mobile app and related educational materials to help family caregivers understand and manage difficult behaviors in persons with Alzheimer’s disease, with the goals of improving caregiver coping, reducing distress, and managing behavioral symptoms. citeturn0search0turn0search5

Act (key details extracted): Title: "Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training for Family Caregivers"; Registration/ID: NCT04489303; Interventions listed: Behavioral – Caring Response App and Traditional Educational/Resources Program; Lead sponsor: Photozig, Inc.; Phase 2, status Completed. This is a non-pharmacologic, behavioral/mobile-app training intervention rather than a drug trial. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Act (drug check): No drug or placebo is involved in the trial—this is a behavioral training/mobile app intervention (Virtual Patient Behavioral Response, Caring Response App) as described in the SBIR/project summary and trial registry. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Reflect: The intervention is intended to help manage behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) via caregiver training and thus maps to the category 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' (interventions aimed at alleviating behavioral/psychiatric symptoms). It is not a biologic or small-molecule disease-modifying agent, nor a cognitive-enhancer drug, so other categories do not apply. Comparable caregiver/virtual training programs target BPSD and caregiver wellbeing. citeturn0search8

Web-search summary (sources used): MedPath/clinical-trial listing for NCT04489303 describing the Caring Response app and study summary; ICH GCP / trial registry mirror with study details; SBIR project description (Photozig, Inc.) describing Virtual Patient Behavioral Response training and app development/Phase II aims; related literature on virtual/online caregiver training for managing BPSD. (Cited sources: turn0search0, turn0search1, turn0search3, turn0search5, turn0search8).
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial (NCT04489303, "Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training for Family Caregivers") evaluates a mobile app (Caring Response) and a traditional educational program to train family caregivers in managing behavioral symptoms of persons with Alzheimer’s disease. This is a non‑pharmacologic, behavioral/supportive care intervention rather than a drug or biologic targeting a molecular pathway. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — Title: Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training for Family Caregivers; Interventions: Caring Response mobile app (Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training) vs Traditional Educational/Resources Program; Sponsor: Photozig, Inc.; Phase 2, Completed; Primary purpose: Supportive care. No drug, molecular target, gene, or biochemical pathway is listed. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: CADRO categories cover molecular/biologic targets (e.g., Amyloid, Tau, Inflammation, Synaptic Plasticity, etc.). Because this trial is an educational/behavioral intervention (caregiver training via app) aimed at managing neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms and caregiver outcomes, it does not map to any therapeutic CADRO target category and should be classified as 'T) Other'. This classification is confirmed by the SBIR project description and app listing showing the intervention is a training app developed under NIA SBIR funding (no pharmacologic agent). citeturn0search4turn0search1

Web-search results used (key sources): MedPath / clinical-trial listing for NCT04489303 describing the Caring Response app and interventions; ICH GCP trial registry mirror with study details and supportive-care designation; SBIR project summary for the Virtual Patient Behavioral Response Training (Photozig, Inc., R44AG057272) describing app development and Phase II trial; App Store listing for the Dementia Caring Response app describing virtual patient/role-playing curriculum. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search4turn0search1
